name: Chicha
cultural_notes: Traditional corn beer of the Andes, dating back to the Inca Empire. Chicha de jora is the most common variety. Often homemade and central to festivals.
manufacturing_notes: Made by fermenting corn (jora), sometimes with saliva for enzymes in traditional methods

name: Makgeolli
cultural_notes: Korea's oldest alcoholic beverage, a milky rice wine. Traditionally enjoyed by farmers. Experiencing revival among young people. Often served in a bowl.
manufacturing_notes: Unfiltered, so it's cloudy and continues fermenting

name: Sake / Nihonshu
cultural_notes: Japanese rice wine (actually a brewing process more like beer). Central to Shinto rituals and celebrations. Quality ranges from table sake to premium junmai daiginjo.
manufacturing_notes: Polished rice fermented with koji mold

name: Palm Wine (Tuak, Toddy, Matango, Emma, Nsafufuo)
origin: West Africa, Southeast Asia, South Asia
cultural_notes: Sap tapped from palm trees that ferments naturally within hours. Known by many names: Tuak (Indonesia), Toddy (India/Sri Lanka), Matango (Cameroon), Emma (Ghana), Nsafufuo (Nigeria). Central to social life in palm-growing regions.
manufacturing_notes: Tapped from palm trees, ferments rapidly

name: Marula Wine
cultural_notes: Traditional wine made from marula fruit. Elephants famously love the fermented fruit. Harvest season brings communities together.
manufacturing_notes: Fruit ferments naturally, often in containers

name: Sato
cultural_notes: Thai rice wine, similar to Lao-Lao but fermented rather than distilled. Popular in Isan region. Often homemade for festivals.
manufacturing_notes: Fermented glutinous rice with starter culture

name: Toddy (Pakistan/Sindh)
cultural_notes: Traditional palm wine of Sindh, despite restrictions. Tapped from date palms, consumed fresh before fermentation advances. Part of Sindhi cultural heritage.
